description.other_details: This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 License. To view a copy of this license, visit http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/.

Derived from: Behavioural observation audiometry (BOA) result, Draft archetype [Internet]. Australian Digital Health Agency (NEHTA), ADHA Clinical Knowledge Manager. Authored: 2013. Available at: http://dcm.nehta.org.au/ckm#showArchetype_1013.1.1390_1 (discontinued).

details.purpose: To record unconditioned responses of an infant or young child’s response to auditory stimuli. To record the interpretation of responses.
details.use:
Use to record child’s Minimum Response Levels (MRL’s) and reflexive responses (eg. APR) to noisemakers and speech. Recorded in the free-field measuring a binaural response.
Use to record an overall interpretation of response levels and response qualities to provide an indication of the probable hearing status. BOA is generally used as a secondary testing technique in infants under 6mo to provide supporting information to objective measures of hearing levels (ABR/SSEP). In cases where an infant cannot be conditioned to VROA, is not developmentally able to perform VROA, or if VROA equipment is unavailable, BOA may be used to obtain information about behavioural hearing.
Please note: - MRL: the lowest intensity level at which a response to a stimulus is recorded. An ascending technique should be used when establishing MRL’s. - dBA: Decibels measured in the sound field using the A scale sound level filter. Using this filter, the sound level meter is thus less sensitive to very high and very low frequencies
Details about assisted hearing devices used as aids in this test should be recorded in the EVALUATION.assisted_hearing_summary.
details.copyright: © Northern Territory Department of Health (Australia), openEHR Foundation

items.items: Observations of an infant or young child’s unconditioned response to sound, and associated clinical interpretation.
Default, unspecified point in time event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The type of stimulus used in the test.

The frequency or range of frequency used by each stimulus will need to be managed in a clinical system. In most situations as a stimulus is selected by the clinician, the relevant frequency or range will be inserted into the 'Frequency' data element.
Lowest intensity at which a response to a stimulus is observed.
The frequency or range of frequency of the identified stimulus.
The test result observations and interpretations.
Narrative description of the reliability of the response, as determined by the tester.
No test result is available for the side stimulated.
Reason why no result is available for the side stimulated.
Overall clinical interpretation of the responses for both ears.
Additional narrative about the test responses, not captured in other fields.
Digital image, video or diagram representing the test results.
Narrative description of factors, not recorded elsewhere, that may influence the response results.
Details to explicitly record that this examination was not performed.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
The response state of the child during the test.
The child was awake, quiet and alert.
The environment in which the test is administered.
Sound-treated test environment that meets audiometric standards for ambient noise.
Test environment that does not meet audiometric standards for ambient noise.
The amount and nature of noise in the environment that may influence the test results.
If testing is conducted in an audiometric booth, this data element is redundant.
The background noise is not likely to compromise test results.
The background noise may compromise test results.
Scale used for acoustic calibration of the test signal.
The test stimuli are calibrated using the sound pressure level scale.
The test stimuli are calibrated using the hearing level scale.
The test stimuli are calibrated using the A-weighted scale.
Presentation of the air conduction test stimulus indirectly to the inner ear through the atmosphere, via the auditory canal and middle ear structures.
The stimulus is presented via a loudspeaker located at least one metre away from the subject.
The stimulus is presented via insert earphones.
The stimulus is presented via external headphones - either circumaural or supraaural.
Moro reflex in response to stimulus.
An involuntary blink of the eye caused by contraction of the orbicularis oculi muscle in response to loud sounds.
Baby has heightened state of arousal in response to the stimulus.
Eye widening, eye movement or eye turn.
Baby turns head in response to stimulus.
